facts.text: Appeal under Article 132(1) of the Constitution from judgment and order dated 12th April 1950 of Bombay High Court.

anchor.surface_text: APPELLATE JURISDICTION Appeal under Art. 132 1  of the Constitution from a judgment and order dated 12th April, 1950, of the High Court of Judicature at Bombay  Chagla J., Bavdekar and Shah JJ.

facts.text: Petitioner was Secretary of Peoples Publishing House Ltd., incorporated under Indian Companies Act, registered office at 190-B Khetwadi Main Road, Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: DAs J.--At all material times the petitioner, who is the appellant before us, was the Secretary of Peoples Publish- ing House, Ltd., a companypany incorporated under the Indian Companies Act with its registered office at 190-B, Khetwadi Main Road in Bombay.

facts.text: In September 1949, pamphlet entitled 'Railway Mazdooron ke khilaf Nai Zazish' published in Bombay by petitioner as secretary of the company.

anchor.surface_text: In September, 1949, a pamphlet entitled Railway Mazdooron ke khilaf Nai Zazish is alleged to have been published in Bombay by the petitioner as the secretary of that companypany.

facts.text: Pamphlet published as a book under section 1 of Press and Registration of Books Act 1867, provisions complied with.

anchor.surface_text: Learned companynsel for the peti- tioner states that the pamphlet was published as a book within the meaning of section 1 of the Press and Registra- tion of Books Act  XXV of 1867  and that the provisions of that Act had been duly companyplied with.

facts.text: Bombay Government viewed pamphlet as news sheet under section 2(6) of Indian Press Emergency Powers Act 1931, published without authority under section 15(1), offence under section 18(1).

anchor.surface_text: The Bombay Government authorities, however, took the view that the pamphlet was a news sheet within the meaning of section 2  6  of the Indian Press  Emergency Powers  Act, 1931, and that as it had been published without the authori- ty required by section 15  1  of that Act, the petitioner had companymitted an offence punishable under section 18  1  of the same Act.

facts.text: Prosecution started against petitioner in Court of Chief Presidency Magistrate, Bombay, registered as Case No. 1102/P of 1949.

anchor.surface_text: A prosecution under that Act was accordingly started against the petitioner in the Court of the Chief Presidency Magistrate, Bombay, and was registered as Case No. 1102/P of 1949.

facts.text: Constitution of India came into force on January 26, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: During the pendency of the proceedings the Constitution of India came into force on January 26, 1950.

facts.text: On March 3, 1950, petitioner filed written statement claiming sections 2(6), 15, 18 of 1931 Act ultra vires under Article 19(1)(a) read with Article 13.

anchor.surface_text: On March 3, 1950, the petitioner filed a written statement submitting, inter alia, that the definition of news sheet as given in section 2  6  of the Indian Press  Emergency Powers  Act, 1931, and sections 15 and 18 thereof were ultra vires and void in view of article 19 1  a  read with article 13

facts.text: On March 7, 1950, petition filed in Bombay High Court under Article 228 to declare sections ultra vires and acquit petitioner.

anchor.surface_text: This was followed up by a petition filed in the High Court on March 7, 1950, under article 228 of the Constitution, praying that the record of Case No. 1102/P of 1949 be sent for, that it be declared that sections 15 and 18 read with section 2  6  and  10 , in so far as they create liability for restrictive measure for a citizen, are ultra vires of article 19  1   a

facts.text: On March 23, 1950, Chief Presidency Magistrate framed charge against petitioner under section 18 of 1931 Act.

anchor.surface_text: During the pendency of this petition the Chief Presidency Magis- trate on March 23, 1950, framed a charge against the peti- tioner under section 18 of the Press  Emergency Powers  Act, 1931.

facts.text: On April 12, 1950, Bombay High Court Bench (Chagla CJ, Bavdekar and Shah JJ) heard petition under Article 228 and dismissed it.

anchor.surface_text: The petition under article 228 was heard on April 12, 1950, by a Bench of the Bombay High Court companysisting of Chagla C.J. and Bavdekar and Shah JJ. ... The High Court accordingly answered the second question in the af- firmative and dismissed the petitioners application.

facts.text: Petitioner appealed to Supreme Court with certificate under Article 132(1).

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner has number companye up on appeal before us on the strength of a certificate granted by the High Court under article 132 1  of the Constitution.

facts.text: Supreme Court heard appeal on January 22, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: 1951. Jan. 22. The judgment of Kania C.J., Patanjali Sastri J. Das J. and Chandrasekhara Aiyar J. was delivered by Das J.
On the 9th December, 1949, the appel- lant was arrested and a prosecution was started against him under section 18 1  of the Indian Press  Emergency Powers  Act  XXIII of 1931
In our opinion, therefore, this appeal fails, and is dismissed.

facts.text: High Court held proceedings under 1931 Act pending at Constitution commencement not affected even if inconsistent with Article 19(1)(a).

anchor.surface_text: The High Court took the view that the word void was used in article 13  1  in the sense of repealed and that companysequently it attracted section 6 of the General Clauses Act ... proceedings under the Indian Press  Emergency Powers  Act, 1931, which were pending at the date of the companymence- ment of the Constitution were number affected

facts.text: Supreme Court agreed with High Court conclusion on second question that pending proceedings can continue.

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, agree with the companyclusion arrived at by the High Court on the second question, although on dif- ferent grounds.

issues.text: Whether sections 15(1) and 18(1) read with the definitions contained in sections 2(6) and 2(10) of the Indian Press Emergency Powers Act, 1931, were inconsistent with article 19(1)(a) read with clause (2) of that article?

anchor.surface_text: Whether sections 15 1  and 18 1  read with the definitions companytained in sections 2 6  and 2 .10  of the Indian Press  Emergency Powers  Act, 1931, were inconsistent with article 19 1   a  read with clause  2  of that article ?

issues.text: Assuming that they were inconsistent, whether the proceedings commenced under section 18(1) of that Act before the commencement of the Constitution could nevertheless be proceeded with?

anchor.surface_text: and Assuming that they were inconsistent, whether the proceedings companymenced under section 18 1  of that Act before the companymencement of the Constitution companyld neverthe- less be proceeded with ?

anchor.surface_text: Learned counsel urged that it was not necessary for him to contend that such inconsistent laws became void ab initio or that all past and closed transactions could be reopened but he contended that on and from January 26, 1950, when the Constitution came into force such inconsistent laws which became void could not be looked at for any purpose and far less could they be utilised for the purpose of framing a charge or punishing a free citizen.

arguments.claim: Void not larger than repeal; prospective declaration does not affect pending; no need for saving clause

anchor.surface_text: The expression void has no larger effect on the statute so declared than the word repeal. ... To hold that a prospective declaration that a statute is void affects pending cases is to give it indirectly retrospective operation and that result is repugnant to the clear phraseology

holdings.text: Article 13(1) has no retrospective effect but is wholly prospective in its operation.

anchor.surface_text: It must follow, therefore, that article 13 1 can have no retrospective effect but is wholly prospective in its operation. After this first point is disposed of, it should further be seen that article 13  1 does not in terms make the existing laws which are inconsistent with the fundamental rights void ab initio or for all purposes.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutes prima facie prospective unless expressly retrospective; Art 13(1) language indicates no retrospective intent; fundamental rights operative only from Constitution commencement.

holdings.text: Existing laws inconsistent with fundamental rights are void only to the extent of inconsistency for future exercise of those rights; they are not void ab initio or for all purposes, and continue for past transactions and accrued liabilities.

anchor.surface_text: On the contrary, it provides that all existing laws, in so far as they are inconsistent with the fundamental rights, shall be void to the extent of their inconsistency. They are not void for all purposes but they are void only to the extent they come into conflict with the fundamental rights.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Voidness limited to post-commencement conflict; giving retrospective effect would obliterate past operation contrary to prospective nature.

holdings.text: Pending proceedings instituted before the commencement of the Constitution under laws that became void under Article 13(1) are not affected and can continue.

anchor.surface_text: The sole point to decide in the appeal is whether proceedings instituted under section 18 1 of the Indian Press Emergency Powers Act, XXIII of 1931, before the commencement of the Constitution of India are affected by its provisions.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Art 13(1) prospective; past liabilities and pending proceedings survive; distinguishes from repeal/expiry without saving; agrees with High Court conclusion on different grounds.

holdings.text: Article 13(1) does not require a saving clause unlike provisions for expiring temporary laws, as it has no retrospective effect.

anchor.surface_text: Learned counsel for the appellant has drawn our attention to articles 249 3 , 250, ... As explained above, article 13 1 is entirely prospective in its operation and as it was not intended to have any retrospective effect there was no necessity at all for inserting in that article any such saving clause.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Prospective operation means no impact on pre-commencement matters; saving clauses needed only for retrospective or expiring laws.

holdings.text: The effect of Article 13(1) is different from repeal of a statute or expiry of a temporary statute; it nullifies inconsistent laws only prospectively for fundamental rights exercise.

anchor.surface_text: The effect of article 13 1 is quite different from the effect of the expiry of a temporary statute or the repeal of a statute by a subsequent statute. As already explained, article 13 1 only has the effect of nullifying or rendering all inconsistent existing laws ineffectual ... only with respect to the exercise of fundamental rights on and after the date of the commencement of the Constitution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Repeal/expiry affects past unless saved; Art 13(1) prospective nullification does not; no retrospective wipe-out.

holdings.text: It is unnecessary to decide whether the impugned sections of the Indian Press Emergency Powers Act, 1931, are inconsistent with Article 19(1)(a).

anchor.surface_text: The High Court considered it unnecessary to deal with or decide the first question and disposed of the application only on the second question.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Resolution of second question dispositive; no need to address first assuming inconsistency.

holdings.text: The appeal fails and is dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, therefore, this appeal fails, and is dismissed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Pending proceedings can continue under prospective application of Art 13(1).

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal dismissed; High Court order upheld; pending criminal proceedings under Indian Press Emergency Powers Act, 1931 not affected by Article 13(1)

anchor.surface_text: It must follow, therefore, that article 13 1 can have no retrospective effect but is wholly prospective in its operation. After this first point is disposed of, it should further be seen that article 13  1 does not in terms make the existing laws which are inconsistent with the fundamental rights void ab initio or for all purposes.
In our opinion, therefore, this appeal fails, and is dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: On the contrary, it provides that all existing laws, in so far as they are inconsistent with the fundamental rights, shall be void to the extent of their inconsistency. They are not void for all purposes but they are void only to the extent they come into conflict with the fundamental rights.

edges.explanation: h2 holds laws void only for future exercise, addressing whether Article 13(1) is retrospective or prospective in i4.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, therefore, this appeal fails, and is dismissed.

The sole point to decide in the appeal is whether proceedings instituted under section 18 1 of the Indian Press Emergency Powers Act, XXIII of 1931, before the commencement of the Constitution of India are affected by its provisions.
In our opinion, therefore, this appeal fails, and is dismissed.

Learned counsel for the appellant has drawn our attention to articles 249 3 , 250, ... As explained above, article 13 1 is entirely prospective in its operation and as it was not intended to have any retrospective effect there was no necessity at all for inserting in that article any such saving clause.
In our opinion, therefore, this appeal fails, and is dismissed.

edges.explanation: h5 holds prospective nullification different from repeal, supporting c12.
h5's prospective nullification addresses impact on pre-commencement proceedings in i3.

anchor.surface_text: The effect of article 13 1 is quite different from the effect of the expiry of a temporary statute or the repeal of a statute by a subsequent statute. As already explained, article 13 1 only has the effect of nullifying or rendering all inconsistent existing laws ineffectual ... only with respect to the exercise of fundamental rights on and after the date of the commencement of the Constitution.

edges.explanation: h5 holds nullification only prospectively, addressing the prospectivity issue in i4.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, therefore, this appeal fails, and is dismissed.
